Description: A truncated conical stamp, perhaps for sealing a wine-amphora or possibly bales or sacks needing a government endorsement. It has an incuse inscription, within a circle encircling a mark, of delta over iota, all apparently cut into the leather-hard clay. When stamped, the lettering would be retrograde. Micaceous brown Nile silt with some white inclusions.
Curator's comments: Terracotta IV Purchased: Greville J. Chester. The iota appears to have been changed subsequently to nu. There is a discussion of the Nitriotes Nome in Bernand 1970: 933-61 and in Bagnall and Rathbone 2004: 108-11; and there are also attestations to its presence in the Duke Data Bank of Documentary Papyri, in the mid-third century BC Papyrus Revenue Laws, in Calderini 1983: 365 and in Strabo 17.i.23 (c.25 bc); it may have disappeared during early Roman times. It was presumably in the area of Nitria, south-east of Alexandria and north-west of Naukratis (Talbert 2000: sheet 74:C3). Probably Ptolemaic, about second to first century BC.
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (3607)
Acquisition name: Purchased from: Rev Greville John Chester
